title: A Study of the Effect of Concomitant Administration of BMS-708163 on the Pharmacokinetics of Donepezil in Healthy Subjects
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to find out if the plasma concentration of donepezil is changed when BMS-708163 is administered at the same time
drug: Donepezil — reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (symptomatic cognitive enhancer)
explanation_target: Reason: The provided study tests whether plasma concentrations of donepezil change when BMS-708163 is co-administered, i.e., it is a pharmacokinetic drug–drug interaction study in healthy subjects. The main investigational compound named (BMS-708163) is a candidate intended to act on AD pathology rather than being a symptomatic cognitive enhancer.

Act: BMS-708163 (also called avagacestat) is an orally bioavailable gamma‑secretase inhibitor developed to reduce production of Aβ peptides (Alzheimer's disease pathology), i.e., a disease-targeted small molecule. citeturn0search5turn0search3

Act: Donepezil is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer in AD (improves cognition but does not target Aβ/tau pathology). citeturn0search1turn0search2

Reflect: Because BMS-708163 is a small‑molecule gamma‑secretase inhibitor that targets Alzheimer's pathology, the trial is best classified as 'disease-targeted small molecule'. Note: the trial itself is a PK/DDI study (not an efficacy trial); donepezil is present as the co‑administered cognitive enhancer, but the investigational pathology-targeting agent (BMS-708163) determines the classification.

Web-search sources used: key references showing BMS-708163/avagacestat is a gamma‑secretase (Aβ‑targeting) inhibitor and summarizing donepezil's mechanism. citeturn0search5turn0search3turn0search1turn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational compound BMS-708163 (avagacestat) is a disease‑targeted small‑molecule γ‑secretase inhibitor developed to reduce production of amyloid‑β peptides (Aβ), so the study’s pathology‑directed agent maps to the CADRO Amyloid beta category. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Act: Extracted details — BMS‑708163 (avagacestat) is a potent, orally bioavailable γ‑secretase inhibitor that lowers Aβ40/Aβ42 in CSF and brain in preclinical and early human studies; donepezil is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer (co‑administered here for a PK/DDI assessment). Classification is driven by the pathology‑targeting agent (avagacestat). citeturn0search1turn0search6turn0search2

Reflect: The CADRO category A) Amyloid beta best fits because γ‑secretase inhibition directly targets Aβ production (an amyloid‑focused mechanism). Note: the trial is a pharmacokinetic drug–drug interaction study in healthy subjects rather than an efficacy trial, but that does not change the mechanistic classification. If additional or different pathology‑directed agents were the primary investigational intervention, a different CADRO category might apply. citeturn0search1turn0search7

Web search results used: PubMed report of avagacestat effects on CSF Aβ (BMS‑708163) — citeturn0search1; Avagacestat product/compound summaries (Tocris / Selleck / MedChem listings) describing γ‑secretase inhibition and Aβ lowering — citeturn0search5turn0search6turn0search9; Donepezil mechanism and clinical profile (StatPearls / PubMed reviews) — citeturn0search2turn0search7
